speaker: The Speaker (Hon. Tony Smith) Took The Chair At 10:00, Made An Acknowledgement Of
theText: Edelman JJ DATE GIVEN:27 October 2017 Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Cth) Appearances: Mr BW Walker SC with GES Ng for Mr Joyce Mr SP Donaghue QC, Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia with Mr PD Herzfeld, Mr MP Costello and Ms JD Watson for the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth MrR Merkel QC with Mr JT Gleeson SC, Mr EM Nekvapil and MsS Zeleznikow for Mr Antony Harold Curties Windsor THE COURT ORDERS THAT: The questions referred to the Court of Disputed Returns by the Speaker of the House of Representatives in his letter dated 15 August 2017 be answered as follow: Question (a) Whether, by reason of s 44(i) of the Constitution[,] the place of the Member for New England( Mr Joyce) has become vacant? Answer By reason of s 44(i) of the Constitution, the place of the Member for New England, the Hon Barnaby Joyce MP, is vacant. Question (b) If the answer to Question (a) is "yes", by what means and in what manner that vacancy should be filled? Answer There should be a by-election for the election of the Member for New England. Question (c) What directions and other orders, if any, should the Court make in order to hear and finally dispose of this reference? Answer Unnecessary to answer. Question (d) What, if any, orders should be made as to the costs of these proceedings? Answer Unnecessary to answer. DATE AUTHENTICATED: 27 October 2017 Senior Registrar New England Electorate Bennelong Electorate Issue of Writ issued a writ for a new election for the electoral division of New England, in the state of New South Wales, the Court of Disputed Returns having declared the Hon. Barnaby Joyce disqualified. The dates in connection with the new election were fixed as follows: close of rolls, Friday, 3 November; date of nominations, Thursday, 9 November; date of polling, Saturday, 2 December; return of writ, on or before Sunday, 4 February 2018. I also inform the House that, on 11 November, I received a letter from John Gilbert Alexander resigning his seat as the member for the electoral division of Bennelong and that, on Monday 13 November 2017, I issued a writ for an election to fill that vacancy. The dates in connection with the by-election were fixed as follows: close of rolls, Monday, 20 November; date of nominations, Thursday, 23 November; date of polling, Saturday, 16 December; return of writ, on or before Wednesday, 21 February 2018. Petitions Committee Report Committee for the 45th Parliament, together with 58 petitions and 13 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented. This report includes 18 petitions requesting action on climate change and 12 requesting reform for online gambling. These are two well-coordinated and passionate national campaigns seeking the ear of local members on matters of concern to them. The committee is impressed with the level of coordination and community engagement that these campaigns have achieved. As a result of this hard work, these petitions continue to engage members and the communities they represent. There are 28 other petitions in this report on a diverse range of matters. A total of 19,444 people have signed these petitions. That's a fantastic level of engagement with the parliament that we are seeing come from our local communities. In keeping with the high engagement in our petitions process, I will take the opportunity to report on a single e-petition that has closed for signatures in this past week, with 48,985 signatures. This is by far the largest e-petition to date, and it's a clear indication that our epetitions system is working as intended. Nonetheless, the committee is still looking at ways to improve the system. We are wrapping up our inquiry into the e-petitions system this week by talking to a group of primary school students, by video link, who have recently been engaged in petitioning the House. The committee looks forward to receiving a fresh perspective from these students, and we are excited about their interest in the petitioning process. I will continue to provide updates to the House on the work of the Petitions Committee and the inquiry into e-petitions.

title: Committees

speaker: Mrs Wicks (Robertson) (10:03
theText: TodayI present the 18th report of the PetitionsBanks This petition of the Citizens Electoral Council draws to the attention of the House that even such institutions as the IMF, the Bank for International Settlements, and the US. Federal Reserve are now warning of a new, far more severe financial crash than that of 2008. Transatlantic and Commonwealth governments have bailed out the Too-Big-to-Fail (TBTF) banks with US$19 trillion since 2008, virtually all of which has been used for speculation; the banks are now 40 per cent larger; and the derivatives exposure of Australia's own banks has soared from $14 trillion in 2008 to $38 trillion now. Moreover, these TBTF banks have repeatedly been caught in criminal activity like drug-money laundering, terrorism financing, mortgage fraud, interest rate and exchange rate rigging, and more. The world must replace this disastrous, corrupt system now, before the next crash. We the undersigned therefore call on the House to do Australia's part, and legislate the following: 1) a full Glass-Steagall separation of Australia's banks to protect normal commercial banking and deposits from the wild speculation of today's TBTF banks; 2) a national bank modelled on the original Commonwealth Bank to create massive new credits to revive our manufacturing, agricultural and other productive industries; 3) a program of major water, power and transportation infrastructure projects, in Australia and in our region, cooperating with China's "One Belt, One Road" program-in which 100 nations are already participating-to spur global economic recovery and provide for an enduring peace. from 3,803 citizens Social Media More than 50% of children under the age of 15 are sitting in their households, unsupervised by an adult, on social media platforms. This is a substantial issue being taken place in almost every household throughout Australia. Young children could be facing major cyber bullying without their parents knowing. Some forms of social media include: Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, Snapchat and Whatsapp. Young children could be getting forced or bullied into doing horrible things and they might not know what to do at that stage of time. Their mind would not be mature enough to cope with it. Based on a study at the Oxford University, 25% of children are not capable of dealing with issues on social media under the age of 15. They could be physically or mentally hurt by people on social media platforms who interact with them online. Children must be appropriate age and be mature enough before they are allowed to use social media websites on their own. We, therefore, ask the House to: Change the limit of the age from when children are allowed to use social media. We request you to change the age limit from 13+, to 15+ to allow more time for the children to fully mature and learn the correct use of social media. Based on facts and evidence we believe the minimum age for social media is 15. from 24 citizens Gender Pay Gap This petition of young student citizens of Australia Draws to the attention of the House: The pay gap between genders when working the same job across all fields. We understand that this problem does not occur across jobs supported by the government but jobs of smaller businesses. The gender pay gap is influenced by a number of factors, including: discrimination and bias in hiring and pay decision, women and men working in different industries and different jobs and with female-dominated industries and jobs attracting lower wages. Among full-time workers, women earn 84% of a man's pay on average, resulting in a full-time gender pay gap of 16% . But this is an increased effort as twenty years ago, the full-time gender pay gap was 17%. Research shows a male barrister gets an average income of

theText: I present the following petitions:$168,766 whereas women earn an average of $59,436 for the same job. This is a difference of $109,330. We therefore ask the House to: Address this issue by creating a new law seeing women and men paid the same across all fields of work. This will eliminate a wage difference between men and women. We ask that if working at the same: experience, quality and for the same hours that they be paid equally. We feel that this is to your utmost importance and would help to stop gender discrimination across Australia. from 34 citizens Climate Change This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Boothby, draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest. We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change – such as more severe heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas – by: committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions; developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use; providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change. from 206 citizens Asylum Seekers This petition of Ringwood Uniting Church members and concerned citizens, draws to the attention of the House: Our concern about the welfare of Asylum Seekers in the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation centre (MITA}. We are aware that certain items are not allowed into the MITA as listed on the Department of Immigration and Border control website https://www.border.gov.au/Busi/Comp/lmmigrationdetention/visiting-a-facility/items-not-permitted-inimmigration-detention However, on a number of occasions visiting detainees, items such as flowers for a birthday, commercially packaged Easter eggs or other forms of celebratory packaged food (which are allowed under the terms with permission} and personal gifts such as books, that pose no danger to the detainee or the MITA, have been denied entry. These items provide a way of showing dignity and compassion to people in detention and form part of acknowledging the personal value of each individual. It is uncertain why these items that nourish a detainee's pleasure for living would be denied or considered contraband. We are further aware that upon a visit, detainees are not allowed bac� to the visitor's room after leaving for a toilet break. This measure denies the basic needs of a human being and punishes them for the natural functions of the body. We the undersigned therefore ask the House to: Conduct an urgent review of the gift policy for the MIT A in line with the stated 'permitted items' from visitors. We further ask the House to investigate the reasons for why a toilet break for detainees prevents them from re-uniting with their visitor. from 237 citizens Gambling This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House: Gambling operators are permitting betting on the outcome of lotteries, with these synthetic lottery operators making no contribution to State lotteries taxes. We therefore ask the House to: Amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 so as to ban betting on the outcome of lotteries and thereby prohibit the operation of synthetic lotteries in Australia. from 65 citizens Gambling This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House: Gambling operators are permitting betting on the outcome of lotteries, with these synthetic lottery operators making no contribution to State lotteries taxes. We therefore ask the House to: Amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 so as to ban betting on the outcome of lotteries and thereby prohibit the operation of synthetic lotteries in Australia. from 411 citizens Smoking This petition of young students of Australia draws to the attention of the House: At the age of 18, young people are getting addicted to smoking. The human mind will be more developed and be able to produce wiser decisions about smoking and how it will affect their future. Australia may be at a high risk of losing population of young citizens due to young people under the age of 18. Every 28 minutes in Australia, one young person dies from smoking and every week one youth citizen of Australia dies from the same cause. This calculated up to at 52 young Australian citizens dying from smoking each year. The young adults (18 years old) are getting depressed over getting separated from family and friends. As a result they can get stressed and even more addicted. We therefore ask the House to: Change the age limit of smoking and buying cigarettes from the age of 18 to 21. When they are 21, they will be more mature and make well informed decisions about smoking. At the age of 18 their life is in danger to die, thus Australia's population will be decreasing slowly just because of smoking and second hand smoke. The lives of the young citizens of Australia, rest in your hands. from 34 citizens Public Infrastructure Investment Extending the jurisdiction of the ACT government to represent South East/West and Tablelands (NSW). For a long time Regional/rural NSW has been neglected by the NSW Government with very little investment in public infrastructure, jobs and education, especially the Southern East and Tablelands. There needs to be a change as people who live there deserve more from their government. The borders of the ACT should be greatly expanded to include the area (draw a line linking) from Batemans Bay, to Goulburn, to Young, then to Wentworth. The area within to the border with Victoria would belong to the ACT. The NSW government has done nothing to improve the lives of those living in the Southern Tablelands, maybe it is time for the Regional Capital (Canberra) to represent the people of South East/West and Tablelands! Regional NSW deserve much more from their government. from one citizen Toxins in Perfumes This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that too many people are being forced out of workplaces due to the unregulated, unnecessary toxins in perfumes, colognes, deodorants and other scented, or de-scented products designed to disguise human odours. The need to wear breathing apparatus has increased dramatically, as has True Allergies to petroleum-based substances. 38% of the population is debilitated when in contact with second-hand fumes of petroleumbased substances, such as Propylene Glycol, in personal hygiene products, which are also a known carcinogen. People cannot speak, at workplaces, wearing facial masks and be heard clearly! We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister and the Attorney General place a ban on the sale and production of Propylene Glycol and other petroleum-based substances in personal products, that can be worn into workplaces and cause fumes to accumulate in hazard quantities, as well as a ban on the use of petroleum-based cleaning products in closed workspaces that do not supply adequate breathing apparatus, or give notice that such apparatus should be used. from 17 citizens Medications The Australian government intends to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, in 2017. The UN Special Rapporteur on Torture has stated: " … forced administration of neuroleptics and other mind-altering drugs is a form of torture." The Human Rights Committee found "psychiatric experiments and forced injection of tranquilizers … to constitute inhuman treatment." Patients and witnesses confirm this. Adverse effects of (misnamed) "antidepressants" and "antipsychotics," imprudently prescribed, include akinesia, metabolic, serotonin and neuroleptic malignant syndromes, dyskinesia, death, substance/medicationinduced disorders mimicking mental illnesses, brain shrinkage, akathisia, inner tension, torment or torture, feeling of impending doom, restlessness with worsening depression, toxic hallucinations, suicide, aggression, and homicide. Genetically compromised metabolizers who experience adverse drug reactions receive forced injections. Prescribers are educated by ghostwritten guidelines to prescribe multiple drugs in large doses when their makers cannot promote them legally because safety and efficacy have not been established in children. Federal government's $73,000,000 proposal "to support the mental health of Australian children" further enmeshes Mental Health services/drug treatment with education, undermining the right to give or withhold informed consent. We ask for:moratorium on the proposal: Policymakers consider forwarded information from Principal Petitioner: An Inquiry with Royal Commission powers into forced medication, informed consent, prescribing practices, medications' adverse impacts: Establishment of psychiatric drug detox/rehabilitation facilities: Revision of Mental Health policy and practice to abate harm, acknowledge UN findings regarding involuntary treatment and meet obligations under International Treaties UNCRPD, UNCAT, UNICCPR. from 181 citizens Communities Funding On behalf of the NRRT Association and Tweed Shire CouncilI am petitioning the house to convince the Federal Government to match the $6.5 million in NSW Government funding for the first Tweed Shire section of the Northern Rivers Rail Trail. This project will see an increase in regional jobs centred around services and tourism, conserve a public asset, help create better connected communities around an active transport network, and help increase forest cover, wildlife links, biodiversity and remove atmospheric carbon with the fast growing indigenous rainforest species we have in the Northern Rivers. We ask that the House commend to the Government that it matches the NSW contribution to this highly worthwhile project in order to see the first section built. from 154 citizens Kokoda Campaign On January 22 1943 Australian troops with only the aid of New Guinea natives and no military combatants from other countries, achieved the final victory of the six month long Kokoda Campaign. Australian soldiers both black and white fought side by side in the defence of Australia from foreign invasion. It was a monumental event in Australian history which is not properly recognised or celebrated. We already celebrate a National Day when the British sent Australian troops to the slaughterhouse of Gallipoli, so why not also celebrate our greatest victory. It is a day that all Australians, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal can proudly celebrate together as a day of unity and nationhood. It is therefore requested that the House declare January 22 of each year as a National Day, in recognition of the final victory achieved on Kokoda on January 22 1943 from 37 citizens Australian Constitution The Australian Constitution is a sterile document that says nothing about who we are as a people and a culture or our common values. There is no statement of basic principles that bind us together. Two principles are required. First, citizen equality within a plural society with parliamentary democracy under the rule of law and second, prior Aboriginal sovereignty, A statement on citizen equality would obviate the need for a Bill of Rights, because all human rights flow from citizen equality. Acknowledgement of prior sovereignty would finally bury the rancid corpse of Terra Nullius. It would then also allow a process of agreement making with our First People and truth-telling in our history as called for in the Uluru Statement. The House is therefore requested to propose a Bill to the Parliament that a referendum be held to out the following two questions: 1. Should the Australian Constitution be amended to state that Australia is a plural democratic society in which all citizens are equal and remain equal subject to the Rule of Law, and that all provisions in the Constitution should be consistent with these four interrelated elements of citizen equality, social pluralism, parliamentary democracy and the rule of law? 2. Should the Australian Constitution be amended to recognise the prior sovereignty of Australia's First People, commit to an ongoing process of truth-telling in our history and agreement making with them, and to the continued sharing of our rich Aboriginal cultural heritage as an integral part of our national identity? from 44 citizens Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency Alpha -1 antitrypsin deficiency (Alpha-1) is a hereditary condition that can lead to early onset emphysema & liver disease. Emphysema in an Alpha -1 patient can begin as early as in their 20s. A cure for Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency remains elusive but there is a treatment option for the associated lung disease. Currently, therapeutic augmentation through intravenous transfusion of Alpha-1 PI (protease inhibitor) is the only available treatment for Alpha-1 lung disease. The US has made augmentation therapy available to patients for over 30 years. Canada and a number of EU Countries alongside the US offer patients Alpha-1 Protease Inhibitor augmentation and they typically experience significant reductions in the rate of decline of lung function towards normal. The long-term quality of life and the lifespan of those with lung disease is improved. In Australia organ transplant intervention is currently the only chance of survival for many. The TGA has recently added two plasma products to the Register for patients in Australia treatment is now tantalisingly close. Alpha-1 antitrypsin patients, families and carers request that the House will with minimal delay approve funding and make this treatment available through the National Blood Authority. We ask you to act in our interests because, as with other sufferers of orphan diseases we are a small group and our treatment needs are currently not being met in Australia002E from 490 citizens Privacy So many countries have given people the right to know if a sex offender is living on their street, while in Australia they're hiding behind the Privacy Act. We want to see if there is a pedophile living on the street that some children, often alone, walk to school. The victims/survivor's never got any privacy so the offender shouldn't just because they're scared. There's such a thing as re-offending, and children live everywhere. We want to know if we need to take that extra step in protecting our families. So therefore, we ask that you approve and provide addresses of known sex offenders to the public eye. from 16 citizens Customs Regulations The Sport of Airsoft is enjoyed worldwide with limited regulatory restrictions. The Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations 1956 controls importation of Airsoft (soft air) devices to Australia. The Regulations require only the Police Certification Test to be satisfied to import paintball markers or imitation firearms. However, the Regulations impose stricter, disproportionate, non-evidence based controls (i.e. official purposes / specified person test, etc.) on Airsoft devices, based on their appearance, even though they are no more 'real' looking than imitation firearms. Furthermore, Airsoft devices shoot plastic pellets that hurt a lot less than paintballs, having an average kinetic energy of ten times lower. However, the Regulations impose stricter controls on fully automatic firing Airsoft devices, in comparison to paintball markers capable of producing more damage. The Regulations also require Airsoft devices to satisfy Safety Tests. The tests are aimed at preventing accidental discharge of firearms causing serious injury. The tests are disproportionate to be applied to Airsoft devices based on the flimsy materials of construction, limited energy of an Airsoft pellet, and the higher forces created by the test than the energy of a shooting Airsoft pellet. Amendment of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations 1956 as follows: Importation of Airsoft devices of any appearance should only require the Police Certification Test to be satisfied; Importation of Airsoft devices of fully automatic firing capability should only require the Police Certification Test to be satisfied; Airsoft devices of all types of propulsion should be exempt from the Safety Tests; Airsoft devices should be exempted from having a unique serial number. from 3,414 citizens Exports To ban the private exportation of Baby formula products overseas. I would like to see a legislation brought forward where it would make it illegal to send Via private parcel/courier/shipment of Baby formula products to any overseas countries from Australia. from 14 citizens Family Law Family court is an emotive issue that ties up courts for up to three years it impedes relationships with children from broken families, children often having to go long periods of time without contact with the other biological parent. Solicitors cost upwards of $350 per hour which is a cost many struggle with if the custodial parent is difficult. we therefore ask the house to introduce the following measures to ensure that time is adequately spent with BOTH biological parents during the time of family law conflict: A) That family resolution centres be presented with more power in the mediation process (so it stays in resolution centres without the need for court and solicitors.) That fines are imposed for people who repeatedly don't show, an agreement that defaults to 50/50 custody if failure to show, court should be avoided, and that any agreements that are made be legally enforceable. B) That mediation services remain a fixed price for all parties. One capped price. not dependant on income. C) That any allegations made after the separation be somewhat scrutinised. That police reports be made available to verify incidents. D) In the event of a breakdown of a relationship a "show cause" application to relocate more then 2 hours away apply prior to relocating, as recovery orders are often difficult to enforce, once children are settled at new location. E) child maintenance to have a stay order applied until custody is resolved to incentivise quick resolution. from 712 citizens Marriage Law Reform Despite the Commonwealth passing anti-discrimination laws for same-sex couples since 2008, these Acts do not provide the same protections, rights, entitlements as "married" couples. The legislative power to pass laws relating to domestic relationships, civil unions, de facto partnerships is vested only in the States, rather than the Commonwealth so non-marriage couples are subject to the laws governing civil unions, de facto partnerships, relationships of their respective State, so there will be inconsistencies from State to State, on a question of law, across Australia. The Commonwealth is only able to legislate on "marriage". The legislative powers under s.51 of the Constitution of Australia should include "domestic relationships, civil unions, de facto partnerships". Although the Australian Bureau of Statistics is conducting a survey on whether the law should change to allow same sex marriage, the result of the survey will not bind the Commonwealth Government to amend the definition of "marriage" under the Act, therefore couples in non-marriage relationships will not benefit at all from this survey, regardless of its outcome. Even if the definition of "marriage" under the Marriage Act is amended to allow same sex marriage, it will still not provide for domestic relationships, civil unions, de facto partnerships. We therefore ask the House to pass a referendum bill to amend s.51 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act to include, in the Legislative Powers of the Parliament, a sub-section for, "domestic relationships, civil unions, de facto partnerships". from three citizens Suicide Suicide is the leading cause of death for Australians aged 15 to 44 and has been described as a global epidemic by various international organisations. Despite the Government's efforts in addressing this issue through the National Suicide Prevention Strategy, Australian citizens suffering from mental health issues are entitled to less support through Medicare than they were five years ago. The current limit of 10 individual allied mental health services per year is not enough to treat most mental illnesses and puts many Australians at risk while discouraging others from seeking help early on. The requirement for a patient to have a severe mental health condition before receiving substantial assistance (under Item 319) is a reactive approach that costs Australia more than it would to provide greater mental health support from the beginning. We therefore ask the House to illustrate Australia's commitment to supporting its citizens' mental health by increasing the number of individual allied mental health services to the previous 18 session maximum with discretion for this to be further increased depending on the patient's needs. from 81 citizens Disability Support Disability Support Pension (DSP) recipients on partnered payment rates are financially penalised due to relationship status being married/defacto despite unique health, pharmaceutical and mobility needs. Welfare reports and news articles demonstrate how DSP recipients are forced to skip/stop: medications, professional medical engagement, dental care, meals, social inclusion; utilities (water, gas, electricity); and accept homelessness as normal. Equitable parity in relationship context amongst those with disability is essential for their household to function harmoniously without disadvantage compared to single DSP recipients. Government has conveniently taken the Biblical belief that 'two can live more frugally than one' however, those with disability, impaired mobility, chronic health or mental health issues require welfare support to reduce societal burden. DSP partnered relationships incur debt through desperation from bank or predatory loans, family, friends and advanced payments cycles that increases duress. Such debts are contrary to the Commonwealth Consolidated Acts, SOCIAL SECURITY (ADMINISTRATION) ACT 1999 SECT 60, Protection of social security payment, (1) A social security payment is absolutely inalienable, whether by way of, or in consequence of, sale, assignment, charge, execution, bankruptcy or otherwise. Financial discrimination must stop. DSP recipients fully remunerated. That "Partnered Rate" is raised equal to the Single Rate of Disability Support Pension payment. The terms "Partnered " and "Single" Rates of DSP be discontinued. That DSP recipients are not discriminated against financially based on relationship or co-habitation status. That DSP recipients affected in the past, current and future by this "Partnered Rate" discrimination be full remunerated. from 16 citizens Medical Care People impacted by disease/injury from workplace incident, motor vehicle accident, public liability, genetic disorders, birth defect, degenerative or slow onset disease receive a diverse range of medical interventions and outcomes through no fault of their own. These patients receive inadequate work-up when symptoms exceed a doctor's ten-point diagnostic criteria defaulting to psychosomatic disorders of the WHO, ICD rubrics. Subsequently, the patient's condition deteriorates into chronic complex disease, permanent disablement with inflated costs to tax payers. Often on low incomes with negligible financial resources, these debts balloon within months of injury/disease onset from delayed medical diagnostic criteria sabotaging critical diagnostic work-up and treatment. Once financial resources are gone, family/friends are sought to support diagnoses/treatments inducing relationships duress from unrealistic reimbursement promises upon recovery. Hence, deterioration, debts, relationship decay, homelessness and social exclusion increases. Affected individuals have absolute inalienable right to medical diagnostics, mobility aids and financial remuneration to navigate disease and permanent disablement. That all diseases/symptoms are given full patient work-up, not defaulting to psychosomatic WHO, ICD rubrics. That diagnostic procedures, subsequent treatments for all conditions that may result in disablement are prompt, without cost to patient or their family. That people whom are permanently disabled from whatever circumstances who are forced to live on a social wage such as Disability Support Pension have an absolutely inalienable right to equally supportive medical, mobility aids and financial remuneration as those who access TAC, WorkCover, Public Liability and any other financial and medical compensatory interventions in Australia. from 10 citizens Health Disparity between diagnosis/treatment of co-morbid chronic diseases and associated disabilities compared to single human diseases results in diverse patient outcomes. Conditions of complex symptomatology known as "medically unexplained physical symptoms (MUPS)", individuals affected by Chemical Sensitivity, Chronic Fatigue and Fibromyalgia Syndromes, a patient can waste decades seeking treatable diagnoses other than misdiagnosis and psychosomatic aetiologies leading to iatrogenic harm, advanced disease, premature death the longer a patient remains misdiagnosed inducing duress for families/friends resulting in debt and homelessness as relationships decay. Research indicates complex MUPS patients visit 12 medical doctors to achieve diagnosis yet fail to manage their conditions due to insufficient financial resource. Current diagnostic pathways for MUPS is inefficient, ineffective and detrimental for individuals. Chemically sensitive individuals viewed as MUPS are unable to access medical professionals due to symptom aggravation from fragrance, cleaning/hygiene products, plants, construction and finishing materials in medical practices and hospitals. Individuals suffering with MUPS be promptly diagnosed including aetiologies, excluding all psychosomatic components of differential diagnosis, that prolonged treatments be withheld until all symptoms are identified, accounted for and appropriately diagnosed to reduce contraindicated treatments for MUPS. That doctors, health care plans, allied health, pathology, imaging, are fully Medicare covered to maximise recovery. The Medicare Safety Net threshold be set to zero permanently for MUPS patients. That FRACGP are informed of peers/specialists regularly diagnosing and treating MUPS patients. That medical clinics be set to accommodate patients with MUPS to minimise chemical exposures throughout the patient's life. from nine citizens Sleep Apnoea Sleep apnea affects many individuals and especially exacerbates those with at least one disability. Besides Queensland, Disability Support Pension recipients have no access to funding for any CPAP machine and related equipment. Subsequently, most DSP recipients endure the symptoms of sleep apnea including fatigue, cognitive dysfunction and find the price sufficient deterrent to not bother monitored testing and treatment. That all Disability Support Pension recipients have defined pathways at a Commonwealth level to access medically appropriate testing and funding for all sleep apnea equipment at no cost to themselves and that regardless of disabilities, all testing accommodates full medical and accessibility needs of each individual. from 20 citizens Media Classifications We want the National classification for Media and the Arts applied to school education programs like "Safe Schools". We want the content of the individual units of programs such as Safe School be schools introduced sexually explicit content they should be held to the same standards that we trust of our commercial communication suppliers and not be able to breach that trust without accountability to a national organisation or ombudsman. Further the Education system regardless of which state must be held accountable for the content they transmit to students to a standard that is trusted by our Australian society-as whole. The National classification for Media and the Arts is such a system. We therefore ask the House to apply the viewer safety rating system of the The National classification for Media and the Arts to education program units in particular the "Safe Schools" program. We ask that any content deemed to be PG be only shown or administered when a parent is present. That "M" rated content is only delivered to students over 15 and that "X " rated content be delivered only to students over 18. We ask that this be a National system that individual education bodies must comply with and be accountable to a national regulator, complete with a system of penalties in place in order to regulate state and private educators to comply. from 352 citizens Insurance Premiums To the Hon. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members of the House of Representatives, Property owners and Residents of the Pilbara in Northern Australia, seek urgent action from the Federal government to reduce the Insurance Premiums available for Home& Contents insurance and Landlord insurance. We believe the findings of the Northern Australia Insurance Premiums Taskforce did not correctly reflect the impact of the high insurance premiums being offered to Pilbara property owners and residents, or did the findings justify the high insurance price hikes that are still affecting policy holders and the Pilbara area does not have a high claim rate. Some insurance premiums now are higher than home loan repayments paid each month, with a quote of $19,000 received for a fibro 3 x 1 rental. We are being unfairly treated as Australian citizens and believe that insurance premiums could be charged at an affordable capped rate for properties that are built and have met the Australian building codes and regulations required for cyclone regions. Your petitioner's citizens of Australia therefore respectfully request that the House of Representatives urgently cap insurance premiums to an affordable amount and consider base premiums are offered upon building standards met. Request that an insurance watchdog is formed to watch over the insurance industry and their practices of offering unjustifiable insurance premiums and unexplained price hikes to regional areas. Request that the Pilbara Region be separated from other RegionC areas that are not built to sustain cyclonic weather. from 96 citizens Child Support The child support agency is based on legislation that is somewhat complex, it applies differently in each circumstance and variable on peoples incomes this leads to people conducting business that is non compliant and subsequently leads to conflict. Family court recognises that child support and custody are not matters that are related however restriction of access increases payments to the custodial parent. The signees of this petition request that child support becomes a fixed amount yearly with the amount to be contributed equally by both parents, that the contribution is not variable amounts based on income, that child support be paid onto a basics card with online portal to view spending. we request all children have the same "worth" so as not to disadvantage lower socioeconomic groups. we ask for the government to consider changing the bracket for how much per dollar is lost for Family tax benefit so that child support does not exceed this amount. we request that overtime and second jobs be excluded from assessments. we also ask that the nights of care percentage be inclusive of days and weeks, reducing assessment on the basis of actual care by the daily rate for days and weeks in the non custodial care. four weeks of care should result in a reduction of the annual amount by four weeks and That capacity to earn not apply in any circumstance as securing full time employment in current job market is difficult. from 651 citizens Medical Services To Hon. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members of the House of Representatives, It has come to our attention that the Federal Government is not fairly funding enough WA medical services such as MRI services per km and capita as it does on the eastern side of Australia. This is grossly unfair to residents in regional Western Australia who are already isolated from affordable medical services. A MRI is a type of Medical service that could save lives and should be taken seriously and supported. At present there is no MRI services available north of Geraldton, up and across to Darwin, or inland to Alice Springs a massive area of Australia that has been left under resourced. Global Diagnostics, medical service provider of a mobile MRI scanner in Port Hedland had to shut their doors after 4 months as they were denied an approved Medicare subsidy under the Diagnostic Imaging Accreditation Scheme. Local residents wanting to use their $800 services could not claim a Medicare subsidy. Public patients from Hedland hospital get sent to Perth through the State Government's PATS service to have an MRI scan carried out in Perth, some 1800kms away spending unnecessary costs on flights. Certain citizens of Australia request the House of Representatives to support the urgent increase of Medicare funded medical services available to Pilbara residents, and approve for a Global Diagnostics mobile MRI scanner to be granted Diagnostic Imaging Accreditation Scheme status, save unnecessary costs and give urgent imagery to patients. from 28 citizens Palfreeman, Mr Jock For the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Julie Bishop MP, to represent australia and Free Jock Palfreeman detained in the Bulgarian State Prison For the house to recognize the imprisonment of Jock Palfreeman to be unlawful, and for The Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs is the Hon. Julie Bishop MP, to act and represent Jock Palfreeman. He has been imprisoned since 2008 from 363 citizens Shipping Suggesting that the House act to ban the shipping of baby formula and other items of necessity to overseas addresses We therefore ask for the House to act to ban the shipping of baby formula and other items of necessity to overseas addresses from 435 citizens Petitions received. Responses petitions previously presented: Parliamentary Expenditure Dear Mr Vasta, Thank you for your correspondence concerning petition EN0103. Australians are entitled to expect parliamentarians spend taxpayers' money wisely, appropriately and accountably. That is why the Turnbull Government is undertaking the most comprehensive reforms to federal parliamentarians' work expenses in a generation, In February 2017, new laws were passed requiring parliamentarians to pay back any work expense claims they receive that were found to be outside the rules. Any amount paid by the Commonwealth that breaches the rules is now a debt owed to the Commonwealth by the parliamentarian. Where an amount is payable by a parliamentarian as a debt to the Commonwealth, the outstanding amount may be recovered from the parliamentarian by action in a court, or deducted from future work expenses that a parliamentarian is eligible to receive (for example a future travelling allowance claim). If the debt relates to a prescribed travel benefit, in most cases, a 25 per cent penalty may be applied to the amount that is recoverable from the parliamentarian. Once the Parliamentary Business Resources Framework is established, the 25 per cent penalty will extend to all work expenses. On3 April 2017, the Government established the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority (IPEA) that has compliance, reporting and auditing responsibilities for parliamentarians' expenses. The independent authority will monitor and adjudicate expense claims by all parliamentarians to ensure taxpayers' funds are being spent appropriately. Parliamentarians' expenses will also be publicly reported more frequently to create a more transparent system. I trust that this information will be of assistance in your consideration of this matter. Yours sincerely from the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan
title: Petitions

speaker: Mrs Wicks (Robertson) (10:05
theText: I present the following ministerial responses toIslam Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 regarding Petition EN0185 on the situation of ethnic, indigenous and religious minorities in the Middle East. Australia is committed to the protection and promotion of human rights for all persons, including religious and ethnic minorities, regardless of their location around the world. All individuals are entitled to respect, dignity and protection from discrimination and violence. The Australian Government deplores the horrific persecution of minority groups at the hands of ISIL, including Christians, Yazidis, Shi'a Muslims and others. We are a member of the Global Coalition to Defeat ISIL, making a significant military contribution and working to counter ISIL financing, flow of foreign fighters and its pernicious ideology. We have committed over $613 million in humanitarian assistance in response to the Syria and Iraq crises since 2011. Since 2015, Australia has welcomed 12,000 Syrian and Iraqi refugees, over and above our usual humanitarian intake, with priority going to the most vulnerable. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) prepares reports on the underlying conditions that are used by decision-makers in protection status determinations. These reports are available on DFAT's website (www.dfat.gov.au). DFAT made a significant contribution to the parliamentary inquiry into the Status of the Human Right to Freedom of Religion or Belief. The submission may include information of interest, and can he read here: http://www.aph.gov.au/ Parliamentary Business/ Committees / Joint/ Foreign_Affairs_Defence_and_Trade/ FreedomofReligion (Submission 333). Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop Australian Citizenship Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your correspondence of 16 August 2017 enclosing Petition ENO 224 concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Australian Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement introducing an English language test strengthening the Australian values statement strengthening the test for Australian citizenship introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community, and strengthening the pledge. I note the petitioners' concerns about the reforms, particularly increasing the general residence requirement and that the reforms will impact all applications received on or after 20 April 2017. The date of commencement was informed by experiences of previous governments announcing reforms to programmes in the portfolio including the citizenship programme. When new policy is announced this can result in significant increases in the number of applications, and consequential delays in the processing of these applications. Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total. This requirement is a key component of the reforms to strengthen integrity in the citizenship programme, and to increase public confidence in the programme. The Australian public expects aspiring citizens to commit to Australia and Australian values, and the Government has determined that four years is an appropriate period over which to measure this commitment. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http.//www.bordergov.au/Trav/Citi. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Climate Change Dear Mrs WicksI refer to your letter of 16 August 2017 to the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, the Hon Steven Ciobo MP, regarding a petition calling for Australia to consider trade sanctions on the United States following the US announcement on withdrawal from the Paris Agreement on climate change (petition number EN0254). As the matter falls within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been passed to me for reply. The Australian Government is committed to the Paris Agreement and to tackling t he global challenge of climate change. The United States remains a Party to the Agreement until it withdraws formally, which at the earliest could occur in November 2020. The United States has said it will continue to participate in Paris Agreement Negotiations while it is a Party, which we welcome. Australia will work through the Paris Agreement and with all countries, including the United States, to find economically sound solutions to transition to a lower emissions global economy. Sanctions, as defined in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Autonomous Sanctions Bill 2010, are imposed in situations of international concern', including `the grave repression of the human rights or democratic freedoms of a population by a government, or the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction or their means of delivery, or internal or international armed conflict.' Sanctions are not appropriate in this case. I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop Welfare Reform Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 regarding petition number EN0256 and the drug testing trial announced in the 2016-17 Budget. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. It is not in line with community expectations that someone receiving taxpayer-funded welfare payments is using that money to buy illicit substances. This directly impacts on their ability to find and maintain sustainable work and become self-reliant. The Government has announced a suite of measures to prevent welfare payments being used to fund drug and alcohol addictions and help people to overcome their substance abuse issues and increase their chances of gaining employment. As part of this suite of measures, the Government will trial a new approach to identifying job seekers with drug abuse issues and facilitating their referral to appropriate treatment. From1 January 2018, 5,000 new recipients of Newstart Allowance and Youth Allowance (other) in the Local Government Areas of Canterbury-Bankstown in New South Wales, Logan in Queensland and Mandurah in Western Australia will be selected for random drug testing. These locations have been selected based on careful consideration of data available on drug usage, crime and health statistics, income support utilisation and the availability of appropriate treatment and supports for drug abuse. Job seekers who test positive will be placed on Income Management to help them to manage their finances and limit their ability to use their welfare payments to fund further drug use. Income Management includes assessment of an individual's priority needs (such as rent and utilities) and the establishment of automatic payment deductions to meet these expenses. The specific measure of Income Management used for the drug testing trial will be based on the Supporting People at Risk measure of Income Management. This measure is designed to support at risk individuals on a case by case basis. This form of Income Management is particularly suitable in relation to the drug testing trial which is designed to support individuals with drug abuse issues to overcome their barriers to work. These job seekers will also be required to undergo further drug testing. Those who test positive to a subsequent test will be referred to a medical professional who will assess their particular circumstances and identify appropriate treatment options. If this assessment recommends treatment, the job seeker would be required to have this included as an activity in their Job Plan. This recognises that job seekers who have been identified as having drug-related barriers to work should be taking steps to address those barriers through appropriate treatment. Participation in recommended drug treatment will also help. either in part or wholly, to meet a job seeker's mutual obligation requirements. Treatment could include, but is not limited to: further assessment services, support and case management, counselling, information and education programs, detoxification or withdrawal management, non-residential or residential care or rehabilitation or pharmacotherapy. This model of drug testing welfare recipients and assisting them to access appropriate treatment is unique compared to what has been conducted anywhere else. Many of the drug testing programs in the US for example, have a different central purpose whereby all of the 14 states with drug testing remove benefits from people who test positive. This is not what we are trialling here. No one gets cut off by a positive test under our system. The trial is underpinned by two fundamental principles: if you mandate treatment, tailored to individual people's needs, it will improve employment outcomes; and if you limit the amount of cash available to someone with a drug abuse problem, it will reduce their ability to underwrite their illicit drug use. The data and evidence shows that this approach of not waiting until people get themselves motivated to seek treatment works, with recent evaluations of drug court mandated treatment in Australia showing a reduction in recidivism and better employment outcomes for participants. The Government will also be committing up to $10 million for a dedicated treatment fund to provide support to job seekers in the trial where existing state and Commonwealth funded services are not able to meet any increased demand as a result of the trial. The details of the treatment fund will be determined in consultation with Primary Health Networks and the drug and alcohol service providers in the trial locations before the trial starts in 2018. The trial will be subject to a comprehensive evaluation to build an evidence base regarding the effectiveness of this kind of intervention in the Australian welfare system. This approach will capture any possible unintended consequences in real time, allowing them to be handled promptly. This measure is designed to help people overcome their substance abuse issues and improve their lives. This trial is not about penalising job seekers who are drug dependent, it is about ensuring taxpayers' money isn't being used to fund illicit lifestyles and testing new ways of helping people with substance abuse issues to overcome them and re-enter the workforce. Supporting job seekers to overcome their substance abuse will improve their chances of finding a job and reduce the risk of ongoing welfare dependency. This will benefit job seekers and the broader community. Thank you again for bringing this petition and the concerns it raises to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Social Services, Mr Porter Member Interests Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 requesting a response to petition EN0261 relating to the Register of Members' Interests. The requirements in relation to the Register of Members' Interests are set out in a resolution of the House, as amended from time to time (first adopted 9 October 1984 am). The Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests has a role in relation to oversight of the Register and in considering certain proposals in relation to it (SO 216). Given this role I have sought, and received, advice from the committee in relation to the requests contained in the petition. In relation to the request for members to declare whether any investment property held (by them and their spouses) is negatively geared the committee notes that the resolution of the House requires members to declare all real property held and the purpose for which it is owned, whether for personal use or investment purposes (paragraph 2(c)). The resolution requires also that members register all assets and liabilities of their own and of their immediate family members, and further requires members to include any interest which, in the opinion of the individual member, holds the potential for a real or apparent conflict of interest with a member's public duties to arise (paragraph 2(n)).The committee does not support a change in the requirements such as to require an express declaration in relation to negative gearing. In relation to the request for members to declare if they (or their spouses) are guarantor for a mortgage for a family member, paragraph 2(f) requires that a member's statement of interests must include 'liabilities indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned'. The committee has determined that paragraph 2(f) includes all liabilities, for example, mortgages. Given the specific terms of paragraph 2, that a member 'shall include the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (1) of the Member's spouse and (2) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support', a member's immediate family is already captured by existing requirements. The committee considers it is not necessary to amend the resolution as this proposal is already covered in existing provisions. I trust this information will be of assistance to you. Yours sincerely from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith Parliament House: Procedures Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2017. requesting a response to petition EN0272 relating to the removal of the daily prayer from Parliament's procedures. The requirement for a prayer to commence proceedings, and the exact form of the words used, are set out in standing orders and therefore open to amendment by the House if it wishes. The issue of commencement with prayers has been examined on a number of occasions and changes have not been supported, perhaps reflecting the tendency of Parliaments to be traditional institutions. The form of prayers has not changed since 1901 except for some additional words that were introduced in 1918 for the duration of the rest of the war. In 2010 the House agreed to add an acknowledgement of country at the start of sitting days, but did not change the form of the prayer. Ultimately, as you know, responsibility for the operations of the House rests with the Members themselves, and any changes to the standing orders can only be approved with the support of a majority of Members. Yours sincerely from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith Parliamentary Terms Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter dated 11 September 2017, referring a petition (EN0274) submitted to the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding parliamentary terms. I am responding as the Minister responsible for electoral matters. The petition requests a referendum be held to extend the current term of the Federal Parliament to a fixed four year cycle which is in line with most Australian State, Territory and local council elections. Historically, changes to Australia's electoral system have occurred in response to the recommendations of bi-partisan inquiries by JSCEM. The Australian Government is committed to improving electoral processes wherever possible. As you are aware any change to parliamentary terms requires a referendum, that if held requires a 'yes' vote from a majority of voters nationally and a majority of °yes' votes in a majority of states to succeed. In 188 this matter was tested with the Australian people. The referendum was defeated with less than a third of the population voting in favour and no states voting in favour. In my personal view, longer parliamentary terms will not necessarily give the Australian people better Government. There is always a risk that governments would be locked into longer terms than they should. Current arrangements maintain pressure on parliamentarians to perform at a high level and constantly explain the policies they are implementing and generate consent and support for them. Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan Family Law Reform Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter dated 11 September 2017, in relation to petition number EN0306. The petitioners request that the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to support the immediate removal of children from a parent known or alleged to be committing family violence, or preventing a child from having a meaningful relationship with another parent or sibling. The Australian Government is committed to taking action to prevent family violence and abuse. and to improve the protections offered through the family law system to those affected by violence and abuse. Effectively responding to family violence and child abuse is a responsibility shared by federal, state and territory governments. The states and territories have responsibility for investigating and responding to child protection issues, as well as for the majority of laws relating to family violence. The Australian Government acknowledges that the separation of the federal family law and state and territory child protection and family violence systems can place children and families at increased risk of harm. On 27 September 2017, 1 commissioned the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) to conduct the first comprehensive review of the family law system since it came into operation on 1 July 1976 and released its terms of reference. The review will be conducted with a view to making necessary reforms to ensure the family law system meets the contemporary needs of families and effectively addresses family violence and child abuse. The ALRC will conduct consultations with stakeholders over the course of its review, and I would encourage the petitioners to make submissions to the ALRC about their experiences. A copy of the media release, including the terms of reference, can be found at https://www.attorney_general.gov.aulMediareleases/Pages/2017/ThirdOuarter/First-cornprehensivereview-of-the-family-law-act-27-September-2017.aspx The Family Law Act establishes the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration in parenting disputes. To reinforce this principle, the Act focuses on the rights of children and the responsibilities that each parent has towards their children, rather than on parental rights. In 2006, the Howard Government introduced significant reforms to the Act which reinforced that the best interests of children arc to be the priority in family law matters. The reforms also placed an increased emphasis on shared parental responsibility after separation, where possible, and ensuring that children live in an environment where they are safe from violence or abuse. In particular, a presumption of equal shared parental responsibility was included in the Act to ensure that, in the absence of factors such as violence or abuse, children can enjoy a meaningful relationship with each of their parents, and are protected from harm. In 2012, the Family Law Act was amended to further prioritise the safety of children in parenting matters by giving greater weight to the protection from harm when determining what is in a child's best interests. These amendments included changed definitions of family violence and abuse, to reflect a contemporary understanding of what family violence and abuse is, including physical and emotional abuse and the exposure of children to family violence. The Family Violence Best Practice Principles, developed by the Family Court of Australia and the Federal Circuit Court of Australia, apply in all cases involving family violence or child abuse (or the risk of either). The Best Practice Principles recognise: the harmful effects of family violence and abuse on victims the prominence given to the issue of family violence in the Family Law Act, and the principles guiding the case management of cases involving allegations of child abuse. The Best Practice Principles can be found at http://www.filmilvcourt.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/fcoaweb/reports-andpublications/publications/family+violence/fainily-violence-best-practice-principles. This year, I asked the house of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs to conduct an inquiry into a better family law system to support and protect those affected by family violence. The Committee adopted the inquiry on 16 March 2017. The inquiry will make recommendations about how the system might be improved. More information, including the inquiry's terms of reference, can be found at www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal_Affairs/FVlawreform. In the 2017-18 Budget, the Australian Government announced an additional $10.7 million for the Federal Circuit Court of Australia, the Family Court of Australia and the Family Court of Western Australia to engage more family consultants. Family consultants are qualified social workers and psychologists who specialise in child and family issues after separation or divorce. This will give courts greater access to independent assessments of: family issues, including the best interests of children. This new funding also includes $180 000 to improve the training available to family consultants. The training will focus on equipping family consultants to provide sound independent assessments to assist the family courts, including about the dynamics and risks of family violence. As1 mentioned above, effectively responding to family violence and child abuse is a responsibility shared by federal, state and territory governments, and the Australian Government is working cooperatively with our state and territory level counterparts on these important issues. That is why, on 19 May 2017, the Law, Crime and Community Safety Council, in its support of the Council of Australian Governments (COAG), established a family violence working group of justice officials to develop measures to improve the interaction between the federal family law, and state child protection and family violence systems. Topics for the family violence working group's consideration include: information sharing between the family law, family violence, and child protection systems risk identification and assessment in the justice system proposed amendments to the Family Law Act contained in the Exposure Draft of the Family Law Amendment (Family Violence and Other Measures) Bill 2017 legislative and other protections for vulnerable witnesses in family law and family violence matters, and improving family violence competency for professionals working in the family law and family violence systems. The family violence working group is co-led by the Commonwealth and Victoria. On 28 October 2016, 1 announced the allocation of $30 million for legal assistance and family law services to support the Third Action Plan of the National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022. Under the Third Action Plan, the Australian Government has allocated $18.5 million over three years to fund legal aid commissions in each state and territory to expand duty lawyer services in family law court registries, integrated with family violence support services. Through these Family Advocacy and Support Services, duty lawyers will provide expert legal assistance alongside family violence support workers delivering trauma-informed services to families. The integrated services will assist families moving between the Commonwealth family law, state child protection and state family violence systems. Additionally, a number of other initiatives are being progressed by this Government across the family law system, including: $12.7 million in the 2017-18 Budget to establish Parenting Management Hearings, to relieve the burden on family law courts by diverting less complex matters into a non-adversarial, less formal forum $15 million under the Women's Safety Package to support twelve specialist domestic violence units and five health justice partnerships, delivering wrap-around legal and social support services an additional $3.4 million in the 2017-18 Budget to expand the specialist domestic violence units pilot program $39 million over three years for community legal centres as part of the 2017-18 Budget, to be directed to front-line family law and family violence services. This additional funding will alleviate pressure across the legal assistance sector while directing Commonwealth funding to the highest priority issues the National Domestic and Family Violence Bench Book, a resource for judges in all Australian jurisdictions to improve understanding of family violence. This includes guidelines for court room management to minimise secondary abuse through court processes for those who have experienced family violence. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope that the petitioners find the information in this letter helpful. I encourage then to engage with the Australian Law Reform Commission in the conduct of its family law reference. Yours faithfully from the Attorney-General, Senator Brandis Asylum Seekers Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your correspondence of 15 August 2017 enclosing Petition PN0069, concerning the Australian Government's asylum seeker policies. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. As a party to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol (the Refugees Convention), Australia takes its international obligations seriously. Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the Refugees Convention and other relevant international treaties to which Australia is a party. With the establishment of Operation Sovereign Borders on 18 September 2013, the Government has focused on disrupting and deterring people smugglers, detecting and intercepting illegal maritime arrivals (IMAs), and supporting regional processing and resettlement of refugees, as well as returns of those transferees not found to be owed protection. Anyone who comes to Australia illegally by boat will be subject to regional processing arrangements and will not be eligible for permanent residency in Australia. The Government's Operation Sovereign Borders policies are designed to safeguard vulnerable people from exploitation by people smugglers, prevent the loss of life at sea and restore the integrity of Australia's borders. Restoration of Australia's border integrity has enabled the Government to increase the annual refugee intake. As a result, the Humanitarian Programme has increased from 13,750 in 201617 to 16,250 in 2017-18 and will reach 18,750 in 2018-19. The 2018-19 Programme will represent the largest offshore humanitarian intake in more than 30 years. Focusing on persecuted minorities, Australia has also welcomed 12,000 refugees from the Syrian conflict zone. The ongoing success of these strong border control policies has enabled the closure of 17 immigration detention facilities. The application of regional processing arrangements has meant that, in some cases, family members arriving at different times or who are not defined as immediate family members may be subject to different arrangements and situated in different locations. The Government is committed to regional processing and regional resettlement and will not facilitate reunion of family members in Australia. It remains open to any regional processing country to permit reunion of family members. This is a matter for the regional processing country to decide and will not be determined by Australia. Where Australia's immigration detention population previously comprised mainly IMAs, the current profile indicates that visa over-stayers and those who have had their visas cancelled under the character test of section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 predominate. Of the last group, many have been found guilty of serious criminal offences. The Migration Act 1958 requires applicants to establish a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion in all areas of their home country. People who are found to be refugees must also satisfy health, character and security checks before they can be granted a visa. People who are found not to be refugees in Australia have been appropriately assessed to determine whether they engage Australia's protection obligations. Where an asylum seeker is found not to engage Australia's protection obligations and has exhausted all administrative and judicial avenues for appeal, they have no lawful basis for remaining in Australia and are therefore expected to depart. Those who do not depart voluntarily will be subject to removal from Australia. Removals occur only after all processing has been completed and do not occur where this would place Australia in breach of its international obligations relating to the return of non-citizens. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Regional Processing Centres Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your correspondence of 15 August 2017 enclosing Petition PN0070, concerning the Australian Government's regional processing and settlement arrangements. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. As a party to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol (the Refugees Convention), Australia takes its international obligations seriously. Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the Refugees Convention and other relevant international treaties to which Australia is a party. With the establishment of Operation Sovereign Borders on 18 September 2013, the Government has focused on disrupting and deterring people smugglers, detecting and intercepting illegal maritime arrivals, and supporting regional processing and resettlement of refugees, as well as returns of those transferees not found to be owed protection. Anyone who comes to Australia illegally by boat will be subject to regional processing arrangements and will not be eligible for permanent residency in Australia. The Government's Operation Sovereign Borders policies are designed to safeguard vulnerable people from exploitation by people smugglers, prevent the loss of life at sea and restore the integrity of Australia's borders. Restoration of Australia's border integrity has enabled the Government to increase the annual refugee intake. As a result, the Humanitarian Programme has increased from 13,750 in 201617 to 16,250 in 2017-18 and will reach 18,750 in 2018-19. The 2018-19 Programme will represent Australia's largest offshore humanitarian intake in more than 30 years. Focusing on persecuted minorities, Australia has also welcomed 12,000 refugees from the Syrian conflict zone on top of this. The ongoing success of these strong border control policies has enabled the closure of 17 immigration detention facilities. The Governments of Nauru and Papua New Guinea (PNG) continue to progress refugee status determinations for people transferred to those countries under the regional processing arrangements. Refugees in Nauru and PNG have various resettlement options: refugees in PNG may settle in PNG; refugees in Nauru may choose to stay in Nauru for up to 20 years or settle permanently in Cambodia; additionally, all refugees can express interest in resettlement in the United States (US). US authorities will apply their own rigorous assessment and vetting processes to decide which refugees are eligible for resettlement in the US, and how and when this will take place. Australia assists PNG, Nauru and Cambodia to provide refugees with settlement support to assist with integration into the local community. Services are delivered through a needs-based case management model and may include cultural and language orientation, employment, education and health linking, income support and accommodation assistance. Settlement services focus on building independence and self-sufficiency. Those found not to be in need of protection by the Governments of PNG or Nauru are expected to return to their country of origin. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Freight Costs Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 4 September 2017 regarding Petition PN0073 on funding to travellers across Bass Strait. I regret the delay in responding. The Australian Government currently operates two schemes to address the additional costs involved in transporting goods and people across Bass Strait: the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme (TFES), and the Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme (BSPVES). Both schemes involve a substantial commitment of Government funding in recognition of the unique geographical challenges faced by Tasmania. In 2016-17, the Government provided $185.4 million under the two schemes. The Government has been providing assistance to alleviate the sea freight cost disadvantage incurred when certain categories of eligible non-bulk goods are moved by sea between mainland Australia and Tasmania since 1976 when TFES was introduced. In 2016-17, the Government provided $137.6 million under TFES to offer Tasmanian industries equal opportunities to compete in mainland markets, recognising that, unlike their mainland counterparts, Tasmanian shippers do not have the option of transporting goods by road or rail. Sea travel to and from Tasmania is equally important and is supported by the BSPVES, which subsidises the cost of the accompanied eligible passenger vehicle and provides support to Tasmanians travelling to the mainland and to southbound travellers, who are largely visitors. In 2016-17, the Government provided approximately $47.8 million under the BSPVES, assisting approximately 190,600 eligible passenger vehicles. Rebates under the BSPVES are reviewed annually to reflect the change to the Consumer Price Index. The latest annual increase took effect from 1 July 2017. The aim of the BSPVES, which is to reduce the cost of seagoing travel for eligible passengers, has been in place under successive governments since 2002. On 13 March 2015, as part of its Response to the Productivity Commission Inquiry on Tasmanian Shipping and Freight, the Government reconfirmed its commitment to the Scheme. In so doing, the Government reiterated that the aim of the Scheme does not extend to equalising the cost of inbound and outbound travel across Bass Strait. The Government has and is addressing recommendations made by the Productivity Commission Inquiry on Tasmanian Shipping and Freight. A recent decision was to extend the TEES to goods going to markets not currently covered by the Scheme if the goods are trans-shipped through a port on the mainland.
